narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The course is structured well, the homeworks are relevant, the reading are interesting!Often, it seemed like some of the homework and exam questions were attempts at reading Melinda's mind, and less about being able to justify an answer that we wrote down.I would like to have had a more public health-oriented textbook. This one, which I admittedly didn't always read, seemed more catered towards medical professionals and clinicians.

One of my favorite classes I have taken at YSPH. Challenging information but well taught. Interactive, and the syllabus was designed very well - from the progression through diseases, the readings included, etc. The only constructive criticism I have would be to vary the lecture style a little more - the two days of group presentations were a start, but also some group exercises / informational clips / case challenges would also be fun and keep students engaged through the whole semester.

Great course, loved all the different disease we went over. I come from a molecular and cellular biology background so this course made me feel at home. I thought the course was very relevant for EMD and provided some great info for a public health perspective.

This was a great class! It was a perfect combination of scientific material and public health application. This was easily my favorite class of the semester and one of my favorite classes I have ever taken.My only recommendation was that the organization in the beginning was a little confusing (the first few weeks). One of the first classes were were assigned something like 12 papers, which was overwhelming. It took a few weeks to get into the swing of things, so I would recommend starting the semester with at least two introductory lectures from Melinda and then moving to sections with Jamie, just to get us used to the format of the class and what our expectations are.

A great course. Lots of material, but interesting stuff. The structure of each class (disease introduction followed by research analyses) was great, and helped students apply their knowledge and understanding to real-world scenarios. It was very valuable to work through those research papers together, discovering connections and expanding our understanding of disease characteristics.Dr. Childs' peanut gallery helped to add color to the classroom.

Sometimes the lectures were rushed. Overall we covered a lot of material and it was a interesting class. I think there needs to be a third test so that there is not so much material to test on at the end.

Great course in infectious diseases. Really enjoyed the combination of biology and public health, and especially the efforts to try to tie relevant aspects of the biologic mechanisms of disease with public health. Homework assignments were, in my opinion, often very harshly graded with minimum feedback. Relevance of some of the reading assignments was questionable.

This course is a very good overview of major infectious diseases, and provides students with knowledge of key concepts that are important for understanding of the spread and control of infectious diseases.

This was probably my favorite course of the semester. I liked the way it was organized by disease but had overarching discussion/theme questions to guide the recurrent points throughout the course. My only suggestion for improvement was to possibly discuss some of the concepts in the homework prior to assigning it. The first assignment (dealing with calculations sensitivity and specificity) was not heavily covered in class and was not discussed in Epidemiology until way later. Coordinating the assignments a little better with the class sequences could have reinforced important skills more.

THIS IS THE BEST CLASS. A wide range of topics are covered in depth; unifying themes throughout make it easier to follow everything. Homework assignments are fun, and the exams are designed to really test your knowledge and show you what you have learned.
Incredible class. I have never learned more from any class I have ever taken.
Great informational course on ID. I feel like a learned a wide range of information.

I greatly enjoyed taking this course. I'm not sure that I have any responses for improvement. I came into this course well-equipped to handle it, but I also thought that the teacher did an admirable job teaching this class, interacting with the students, encouraging student participation, covering interesting and relevant topics, giving breadth and depth in the coursework and clearly laying out expectation for the course. I felt I learned a lot and I had a great time taking this course.
Great course. I'm CDE and very glad I took it.
Good organization, I loved the slides!Weaknesses: the TA
Strengths: LecturesWeakness: grading of the homework
This class is perfect as is.
Awesome course! Learned a lot and really felt engaged with the coursework. Easy to follow slides and the course really makes you think.

I think this is a good introduction into the basics of infectious diseases. Melinda is a good lecturer with very logical lesson plans and a good sense of humor. Really enjoyed having her and Jamie Childs as instructors.
The text and articles were excellent. Homework assignments were interesting and helpful. Both Melinda and Jamie were great lecturers.

The course was incredibly strong. We learned the desired content, which was very extensive and informative. The course helped me leave with a good understanding of infectious diseases, and gave me new perspectives on epidemiology, outbreaks, and infectious disease.

Interesting but not good for people who don't have a biology or science background. There should be a minimum prerequisite of this course of biology and/or microbio in order for students to actually benefit from it.

It's weird but I wish we had more homework assignments. For weeks we had no assignments, I forgot a lot of what we learned because it wasn't reinforced in any way. Also, these assignments could have contributed to our grade to give us more of a boost.

This course was a good overall introduction to many important infectious diseases. The content wasn't very in-depth about individuals diseases, but it was a very good introductory course. I learned a lot from this course

I think this course is too general. It's mostly basic information we could easily look up in a wikipedia article. There is some learning of concepts in public health that can apply to other courses and situations, but not as much as I would like. I think individual courses based on say STIs, GI, vector-borne diseases, whatever would be more useful than making everyone take a very broad overview.

This course was fantastic! It was difficult but provided a great review of infectious disease and a wonderful approach to ID that I had never experienced in my prior years of education. I thoroughly enjoyed it!

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is a great instructor. She knows the material very well (sometimes I'm amazed how one can have such a vast body of knowledge stored in the brain) and generally can explain things well. She cares a lot about students learning and she loves the material.I also think Melinda does an excellent job of bringing critical thinking into the public health classroom. Public health is sometimes far too descriptive, far too focused on the cold hard facts. I really appreciate her ability to bring a liberal-arts tone to things and wishit happened more in classes at YSPH.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  She made the class interactive and wrote very clear slides. She always made sure to re-emphasize complicated topics in the next class so that everyone followed along. I also liked the "questions to ponder" at the beginning of each class to get us oriented and thinking critically. I liked her dry humor, and I walked out of every class feeling like I learned a lot, and I could remember the information for weeks to come. Professor Pettigrew is one of the best professors I have had at YSPH.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Amazing teacher. She really knows her stuff about different pathogens and doesn't BS students. She provides great lectures and is really very interesting. Very funny!

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda might be my new favorite professor of all time. She is approachable, smart, an interesting lecturer, organized, aware of her students -- everything you could want in a teacher. She should definitely keep teaching the first class for EMD students (unless she wants to teach more classes I'll be taking)!

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Professor Pettigrew is a wonderful instructor. She always brought a smile to class, and was engaging and entertaining. Her passion for the subject was apparent. She encouraged class participation, and encouraged students to reason through public health scenarios in class.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew seemed very interested in teaching and asked us thought provoking questions. I wish we had done more in class activities.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Great slides and organized lectures. Great interaction with students and answered everyone's questions.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew is great!

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda was a very entertaining and engaging lecturer. I enjoyed her explanations and the way the slides were presented/discussed. I can't really think of any suggestions for improvement.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is just the best. She is an engaging instructor and her lessons are always enjoyable. She responds promptly to student feedback. Take this course if only to take a course with her!
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is awesome. Probably one of the best professors I have ever had. She is passionate, funny, and knows EVERYTHING.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is super cool and funny. I truly enjoyed her as a lecturing and she did a great job of answering my questions after class.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  I enjoyed learning from Miranda. She engaged the class well, and held us to high, but fair standards. Perhaps she could have been a bit clearer about her expectations for memorizing for the exams, but ultimately most of the people I spoke to thought the exams were hard but fair and she was an excellent and well-informed instructor.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Great job.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  She was great! good sense of humor, and she never made you feel stupid, she always took the time to explain something if you asked. She was also really approachable and made herself available for office hours and extra help. I learned lots from her.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Very approachable and available to talk whenever I had a question.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Best professor I've had so far at Yale.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  GREAT professor. She is fun and engaging, without terrifying you for an answer. Makes you think and very straight to the point. Of all the classes that I have taken, this one was the one I was most excited to attend.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is an excellent lecturer and really ensures that her students understand the material. Jamie Childs is also a great lecturer. They work well with each other and with Ryan, the TA.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda is a fantastic instructor. She gives clear, concise definitions, answers questions, engages the class, and is highly informative and entertaining. I really enjoyed her lectures, and would recommend her to anyone.

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Melinda was good but lacked excitement in her discussions which often made it difficult to stay focussed on subject matter that already very difficult to grasp. She was also a bit of a tough grader on homeworks.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  Dr. Pettigrew was an engaging instructor who was accessible and relatable. She gave clear explanations on content, and she made expectations clear.
Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  she's great

Instructor: Melinda Mary Pettigrew  She was enthusiastic, very knowledgeable, and entertaining. She turned what could have been a very dry subject into an interesting and engaging course. She was wonderful to have as a professor!

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Didn't have much interaction with Ryan. He seemed very knowledgable, but wasn't always the most approachable.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  It was nice to have a TA who is participating in lecture. Sometimes comments on homework or grade deductions were not clearly explained.

Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Grading seems to be arbitrary. Didn't really add to the class as much as I would have hoped. Could have provided resources for students or done something beyond the bare minimum.

Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  I really liked Ryan. He was fair, thoughtful, and really interesting. I actually went to his office hours to clarify some ideas I was struggling with and he's just a straightforward, helpful guy. I also appreciated the way he graded; it became quickly obvious what his expectations were. He's a good choice for a TA.

Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Ryan is a brilliant fellow and a nice guy. He was able to respond to students' questions and concerns, and often provided useful insight in class.He could probably use a haircut.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Ryan's comments on assignments were sometimes not helpful and he seemed to be a harsh grader.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Did not really understand the TA's role in the course
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Ryan is great and very helpful!
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  I did not interact enough with Ryan to offer much feedback.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  As a part of the ID dream team, Ryan was an excellent TA. Responsive, helpful, friendly.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Ryan was great.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Ryan gave some commentary inside class and was a fine grader.

Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Iwent to Ryan's office hours only once. In class he contributed well. However, he hadn't actually taken the class before, so he didn't know many of the questions I went to ask him. He was game to look it up and ultimately proved helpful, but he wasn't as on top of the material as I had been hoping.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  N/a

Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  I hate to be rude, but I did not like him at all. He is a fine person, but way way wayyyy too harsh of a grader and too self-important. He was a harder grader than the actual professor! I also didn't care for the fact that he would try to speak out a lot in class after the professors, to show off his knowledge or to have the last word I do not know. Other than that he is okay. But needs to calm down with taking away points carelessly.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Too harsh on grading homework
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  He was good. I felt that he knew a lot about the subject. No qualms.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Ryan is extremely responsive to questions, and he also offers a helpful perspective during lectures.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Couldhave been more in touch and engaging but was there for office hours when I reached out to him.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  Ryan contributed to discussions in class and graded assignments on time.
Instructor: Ryan Henry Boyko  a little tough with the grading

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A great course - the best one I have taken at YSPH yet! Although requires a lot of bio, I would recommend this course to students of any division.
You absolutely have to take it if you want to learn about infectious diseases.

This class surveys infectious pathogens, outlining their biological mechanisms as well as epidemiological significance. You should absolutely take it -- it was one of the best classes I have EVER taken! The more work you put into it the more you get out of it.
This course surveys the mechanisms and epidemiology of some of the most widespread infectious diseases, focusing on aspects of public health.
Very interesting introduction to EMD
Amazing course and would definitely recommend to other students. Prior biology knowledge is recommended, however -- a lot of biology involved in the course.
The course would be somewhat difficult for a student with no background in biology and genetics, but it is definitely worth taking.

I would highly recommend this course for anyone interested in infectious disease. It's a great introduction to some of the highest impact infectious diseases and strategies used to deal with them globally.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT This is literally one of the best classes I have taken in 5 years at Yale.
Incredible class to learn the specifics of infectious disease transmission.
TAKE IT

I would absolutely recommend this class to a fellow student. It is a lot of work, but it is very good and the material is very interesting. It is bio intensive, but the professor does her best to make the course accessible to everyone and ALWAYS makes sure to ask if there are any questions.
If you are CDE, take it!
Yes! You will learn a lot in a very structured way.
Great course!! Learned a lot
Yes- such a fun and interesting class even if you aren't a science person

I would definitely recommend this class to another student. Beware though, a bit science heavy for those who have not taken biology courses, but this should not deter you from taking the course. You will learn a lot and the biology isn't too hard.
Highly recommend this class, even for non-EMD students.
Yes- if they have a science background!
I would recommend this course to anyone wanting a basic course on infectious diseases and related issues (like vaccination).
yeah, not like you have a choice if you're in EMD. it's not bad

I would definitely recommend this course to other students! It was challenging and forced me to think outside the box I was used to, but this was definitely one of my favorite experiences at Yale thus far.
